newsitem.title: UK: United News agrees to take stake in DTN.
newsitem.headline: United News agrees to take stake in DTN.

text.p: United News & Media Plc has agreed to take a 30 percent stake in DTN if that consortium wins a licence for UK digital terrestrial television (DTT) services, United said on Thursday.
United said the cost of the stake would be a maximum of 120 million pounds ($195 million) over a four-year period. DTN is wholly owned by NTL Inc.

DTN has applied for three licences to operate DTT multi-channel services when they are launched in Britain next year.

It faces stiff competition from British Digital Broadcasting, a heavyweight consortium grouping BSkyB, Carlton and Granada. The Independent Television Commission is expected to award the licences in the next few weeks.

Digital terrestrial television would offer viewers at least 30 channels and is broadcast from land-based transmitters to rooftop aerials. It is seen as an attractive option for Britons who do not want to sign up for 200-channel digital satellite or cable packages.

United News & Media already has extensive television interests through its two regional commercial stations, Anglia and Meridian, plus its stake in the recently launched Channel 5 terrestrial station.
